items.title: (Survivor Radio 4 _ GUS, THE JANITOR)
items.text:
(Survivor Radio 4 : GUS, THE JANITOR)


DAY 1 — Gus Broadcast #1
Gus:
Uh. Hello?
Is this thing on?
Yeah. Okay.
This is Gus. Facilities management. Or… I was.
Now see, I don’t know where everybody went, but I gotta say, the east wing looks better without teenagers draggin’ mud through it.
You ever notice how folks’ll complain about the smell of bleach, but nobody complains when the place smells like feet?
Standards, people.
Anyway, if anyone’s still around — somebody left a cart of canned peaches in the cafeteria.
I took two. Not greedy. Just practical.
Also, whoever’s been moanin’ outside the gymnasium at night?
You gotta hydrate. That’s not healthy.
Alright. I’m gonna go fix the flickerin’ light in the stairwell.
Can’t have chaos and poor lighting.
That’s how accidents happen.
________________




DAY 2 — Gus Broadcast #2
Gus:
Okay.
Now I don’t mean to alarm anybody.
But I was mopin’ the hallway by science lab three — because SOMEONE spilled somethin’ suspiciously chunky —
and there’s folks wanderin’ around real slow today.
Very unmotivated.
Nobody respondin’ to “Excuse me.”
That’s rude.
Now, I tried tappin’ one on the shoulder with my mop handle.
Didn’t react much.
So I assume they’re union.
Anyway.
If you’re out there, please stop leavin’ doors open.
Security is important.
And if you’re feelin’ under the weather, maybe lie down somewhere comfortable instead of in the middle of the corridor.
You’re creatin’ a trippin’ hazard.
Thank you.
________________




DAY 3 — Gus Broadcast #3
Gus:
Alright.
I think we need to talk about the smell.
It’s gettin’ persistent.
Now I’ve dealt with gym locker rooms in August. I’ve dealt with cafeteria milk incidents. I have SEEN things.
But this?
This is ambitious.
Also — small note — if you’re gonna bang on the supply closet door for six hours straight?
You better be willin’ to help reorganize the shelving when I let you out.
Because I just alphabetized the solvents.
And I will not be doin’ that twice.
I dunno what’s goin’ on exactly.
But I will say this.
If this is some kind of drill?
You’re all failing.
On the bright side though—
Parking’s never been easier.
Alright. Gus out.
I’m takin’ my break.
And if anyone touches my thermos?
There will be consequences.
________________


DAY 4 — Gus Realizes
Gus:
…Alright.
Okay.
So.
I may have misjudged the situation.
Now, I’ve been in facilities long enough to recognize patterns.
And when multiple individuals ignore direct verbal instruction, exhibit poor hygiene, and attempt to bite you—
That’s not union.
That’s somethin’ else.
I was in the cafeteria this morning.
One of ‘em slipped on a patch I’d just mopped.
Didn’t even try to catch himself.
That’s when it hit me.
They’re not slow.
They’re gone.
…
Well.
That’s unfortunate.
Anyway.
Blood stains come out easier if you hit ‘em before they set.
Cold water first. Always.
Hot water cooks it in.
If anybody’s still alive and listenin’—
clean as you go.
World might be endin’.
But grime is a choice.
Gus out.
I got the west hallway lookin’ respectable.
________________


DAY 5 — The Fall of Linda
Gus:
I don’t have much to say today.
Linda snapped.
Right at the handle.
1992 composite shaft.
They stopped makin’ ‘em like that after the budget cuts.
I warned ‘em.
Nobody listens.
I was clearin’ the front office.
Had three of those biters comin’ down the stairs.
Linda held.
Long as she could.
Good reach. Good balance.
Saved my knees more times than I can count.
Then—
crack.
Split clean.
…
I had to finish the job with a broom.
A broom.
You ever try defendin’ yourself with somethin’ meant for dust?
Humiliatin’.
Anyway.
I buried her out back.
Near the flagpole.
Seemed appropriate.
If anyone finds a decent hardwood handle out there—
let me know.
Standards still matter.
Even now.
Gus out.
________________


DAY 6 — The Burnisher Incident
Gus:
Alright.
So I’d like to address the situation in the main lobby.
First of all—
who unplugged the floor burnisher and left it crooked?
You can’t just abandon a machine like that.
That’s how cords get tangled.
Anyway.
I was runnin’ it this morning. Figured if we’re gonna have the end of civilization, we can at least have a respectable shine on the tile.
Midway through the second pass, I notice a crowd gatherin’.
Thought maybe folks were finally admirin’ the gloss.
Nope.
Just more of those shamblers.
Now here’s the thing about a commercial burnisher—
High torque.
Heavy chassis.
Good forward momentum.
You lean into it, it does the rest.
And let me tell you—
it did the rest.
…
Lobby’s clear.
Very clear.
However—
there are… fragments.
Everywhere.
And someone bled directly onto the grout lines I sealed last week.
Unacceptable.
If you’re operatin’ heavy machinery during a crisis, please be mindful of splash radius.
Also, small note—
if you see a man pushin’ 90 pounds of industrial equipment toward you at speed?
Step aside.
That’s common courtesy.
Anyway.
I’ll be in the lobby for the next few hours.
Tryin’ to get this back to presentable.
Gloss is gone, obviously.
But we’ll recover.
We always do.
Gus out.
And if anyone touches the extension cord—
I will know.
________________


DAY 7 — Survivor Frequency Crossover
[static crackle — overlapping frequencies]
Gus:
 Uh—
There’s… another signal on this channel.
You’re crossin’ lines, ma’am.
This is a public frequency.
You can’t just—
…well. I suppose you can.
Erin (calm, amused):
 I’ve heard about you.
Lobby burnisher incident.
Grout preservation specialist.
You sound busy.
Gus:
 Standards don’t collapse just because society does.
And for the record, that burnisher’s torque did most of the work.
I was merely guiding.
Erin:
 That’s usually how it works.
You guide.
The machine follows.
Gus (grunts approvingly):
 Finally, someone who understands equipment.
You mop?
Erin:
 When I have to.
Cold water first for blood.
Gus:
 …Correct.
Hot water sets it.
Most people don’t know that.
Erin:
 Most people don’t pay attention.
You do.
Gus (pause):
 Used to have a mop.
Named her Linda.
Composite handle. ‘92 model.
Good balance.
Snapped last week.
I buried her.
Flagpole.
Seemed right.
[short silence]
Erin (gentler):
 You didn’t lose her.
You learned her.
Every mop you hold now—
that balance, that grip, that instinct?
That’s Linda.
She lives in your hands.
And in the shine you leave behind.
[longer pause — Gus exhales]
Gus:
 …That’s a ridiculous thing to say.
Erin:
 I know.
Gus:
 …
But it’s… structurally sound.
Erin (smiles in voice):
 Standards matter.
Even now.
Especially now.
Gus:
 You keep your corners clean, ma’am.
Erin:
 You keep the floors shining, Gus.
Music persists.
And so does good work.
Gus (quietly):
 …Copy that.
Gus out.
Erin:
 Survivor Frequency signing off.
Take care of your tools.
And each other.
________________


DAY 8 — Linda Returns
Gus:
Alright.
I’ve got an announcement.
Found a replacement handle in the maintenance shed behind the gym.
Solid hardwood. Good grain. No warping.
Took some adjusting.
But she’s responsive.
I’ve named her Linda.
Tradition matters.
Now before anyone gets sentimental—
this is not the same Linda.
This one’s… sturdier.
Less flex in the wrist.
Good reach under cafeteria tables.
Very important.
…
School’s secure.
East wing barricaded.
Gym doors chained.
Science lab cleared.
And for the first time in a week—
it smells like lemon solvent again.
As it should.
Now here’s the situation.
I’ve been hearin’ chatter on the Survivor Frequency.
Folks lookin’ for shelter.
Talkin’ about regrouping here.
At the school.
Which is fine.
Community’s important.
But let me be very clear about something.
If you come into this building—
you wipe your boots.
You don’t leave wrappers in the stairwell.
You do not—
under any circumstances—
track mud across a freshly sealed hallway.
I did not wrestle a lobby full of biters with industrial equipment
just to watch someone drop sunflower seed shells on my tile.
We will survive.
But we will survive clean.
Linda and I are prepared.
Are you?
Gus out.
And bring your own trash bags.
________________


DAY 9 — New Tenants
Gus:
Alright.
We’ve got occupants.
Three, countin’ me.
Jordan. Senior. Used to roam these halls before all this went sideways.
Good kid.
Polite.
Carries his weight.
Bit too into this… “grunge” business, though.
All that flannel and sighin’.
I told him, “Son, if you’re gonna be melancholic, at least make it melodic.”
We’ll get him listenin’ to Tom Petty yet.
That’s structured sadness.
Builds character.
Now.
His uncle Derrick.
Derrick’s… enthusiastic.
Walked in yesterday with what I can only describe as a “liberal application of blood.”
Drippin’.
Onto tile I personally burnished.
I pointed it out.
Respectfully.
Said, “Sir, you appear to be leakin’.”
He told me to shove it.
Which I found unnecessary.
But I don’t take offense.
People cope different.
Still handed him a rag.
He used it.
Poorly.
We’re workin’ on it.
School’s still secure.
Cafeteria’s operational.
Gym’s off-limits unless supervised.
Jordan’s sweepin’ without complaint.
Derrick leaves cans in places cans do not belong.
We’ll adapt.
That’s what we do.
One hallway at a time.
Gus out.
And if you’re gonna bleed—
at least aim for linoleum.
________________


DAY 10 — “Fighting Mop”
Gus:
Jordan’s got that racket on again.
“Nirvana.”
Says it’s the future of music.
I told him the future sounds like feedback and unfinished drywall.
He says that’s the point.
I don’t see how that’s a point.
“Smells Like Teen Spirit,” he says.
Well, I’ve worked in locker rooms.
Teen spirit smells very specific and it ain’t this.
…
Still.
Second chorus hit.
It’s got… momentum.
Can’t deny momentum.
Structured chaos.
Reminds me of a floor burnisher on uneven tile.
Takes a minute to appreciate.
Anyway.
Important announcement.
I’ve modified Linda.
Reinforced the collar.
Weighted the head slightly.
Wrapped the grip.
She’s no longer strictly custodial.
She is now—
a fighting mop.
Multi-purpose design.
Jordan thinks that’s “metal.”
I told him metal is a material, not a personality.
…
Hold on.
Derrick?
You’re walkin’ funny.
You good?
…
Derrick.
Stop.
You’re drippin’ again.
We talked about—
…
Jordan.
Radio down.
Now.
[muffled scuffle sounds — impact, breath, scraping tile]
Gus (strained but steady):
 Push him toward the lockers.
Not the hallway.
I just waxed that—
Now!
[thud — heavy metallic locker slam]
Good.
Jordan— sweep the leg.
I’ll handle upper structure.
[solid impact — wet crack]
…
…
Well.
That’s… unfortunate.
Jordan, you alright?
…
Yeah.
Me too.
Linda held.
Good torque.
Minimal splatter radius.
We’ll need solvent.
Strong one.
…
Jordan.
Turn that song back on.
________________


DAY 11 — “Left the Tape”
Gus:
School’s quiet this mornin’.
Quieter than usual.
Jordan left.
Middle of the night.
Didn’t wake me.
Left a note on the faculty desk.
Said he didn’t want to slow me down.
Which is ridiculous.
I move at a very reasonable pace.
…
He had the decency to say goodbye.
Left his Nirvana tape on the counter.
Labeled it in marker.
Underlined twice.
I appreciate proper labeling.
Saves confusion.
He took one of the flashlights.
The good one.
Smart choice.
Marked the map before he left.
Also smart.
I don’t blame him.
School’s secure.
But it ain’t the world.
And he’s not a boy anymore.
He cleared lockers.
Held the line.
Didn’t freeze.
That makes him a man.
Makes me proud.
…
I put the tape in earlier.
Played it through.
Still sounds like unfinished drywall.
But I let it run.
Momentum’s momentum.
Linda and I’ll hold the fort.
If you’re out there, Jordan—
keep your corners clean.
Gus out.
________________


DAY 12 — “Reinforcements”
Gus:
Got company again.
Fella named Johnson.
Heard me on the frequency.
Said if a man cares that much about grout lines, the building’s probably worth stayin’ in.
Fair assessment.
Johnson brought tools.
Actual welding rig.
Proper mask.
Didn’t even burn the paint.
We reinforced the east-facing windows.
Metal plates, clean seams.
Good work.
Very tidy.
He’s got a family with him.
Two kids.
Quiet ones.
Which I respect.
They stay outta the hallways unless necessary.
Johnson asked where to set up.
I told him:
Anywhere that doesn’t block access to emergency exits.
He laughed.
Good sense of humor.
He’s stayin’ the week.
Helpin’ secure the roof access tomorrow.
He even brought provisions.
Canned goods.
Water jugs.
Handed me a stack and said it was “for hospitality.”
Now I didn’t charge admission.
But I won’t argue with generosity.
Good man.
Oddly generous, actually.
But I don’t question kindness.
World’s short on it.
School’s lookin’ stronger today.
Windows plated.
Doors reinforced.
Smells like lemon again.
Feels… operational.
If you’re thinkin’ about comin’ through—
bring somethin’ useful.
Or at least bring your manners.
Gus out.
And if you weld near tile—
lay down cardboard first.
DAY 13 — “Company”
Gus:
School’s louder now.
Not in a bad way.
Johnson’s kids run light-footed.
I taught ’em that.
No heel-striking on tile.
Respect the surface.
Johnson’s wife—
makes a decent stew.
Uses too much salt.
But it’s warm.
And warm matters.
We ate in the cafeteria tonight.
Proper tables.
No loiterin’.
Johnson said it felt almost normal.
I don’t think that’s the word.
But it felt… steady.
I watched the kids draw on scrap paper.
Heard laughter echo in the hallway.
For a minute there—
I thought about my own.
Had a wife once.
Two boys.
They wanted me home more.
Hard to explain pride in polish to people who don’t see the shine.
Janitorial work ain’t glamorous.
But it’s honest.
I chose it.
And I don’t regret that.
Still.
Havin’ voices in the hallways again…
It’s good.
World’s a mess.
But this corner of it?
Presentable.
Johnson says we’re buildin’ somethin’.
Maybe we are.
If we are—
it’ll be level.
Gus out.
And if you’re settin’ the table—
line it up straight.
________________


DAY 14 — “Command Structure”
Gus:
We’ve got numbers now.
Six new faces since yesterday.
One fella brought a toolbox.
One brought chickens.
One brought opinions.
Johnson’s been talkin’ more.
Gatherin’ folks in the cafeteria.
Pointin’ at maps.
Assignin’ shifts.
Security, watch, rationing.
Good ideas.
Organized.
I don’t mind.
Someone’s gotta coordinate.
And I’ve got floors to burnish.
Truth is—
I’m better with surfaces than speeches.
Johnson’s voice carries.
People listen.
Kids stick close to him.
He’s got that… projector energy.
I’ve got extension cords.
Different roles.
He asked if we should block off the auditorium.
Said it’s a liability.
I said it’s hardwood.
Needs maintenance.
We compromised.
He runs the perimeter.
I run the polish.
Fair trade.
School’s busier now.
Boot prints everywhere.
But they wipe ’em.
Mostly.
I’ll give him this—
he enforces “no mud.”
That earns respect.
Community’s formmin’.
Has a rhythm to it.
Not perfect.
But steady.
And steady’s enough.
Gus out.
And if you’re holdin’ a meeting—
push the chairs back in after.
DAY 15 — “Unsung”
Gus:
Heard some whisperin’ yesterday.
Couple of the new arrivals.
Didn’t think I could hear.
Said I was “just the janitor.”
Said it like it meant “optional.”
Now I don’t take offense.
People don’t understand infrastructure until it fails.
Johnson’s been restructurin’ space.
Moved some cots into the library.
Stacked supplies in the teacher’s lounge.
Efficient enough.
But he didn’t account for ventilation.
Or weight distribution on those old shelves.
I mentioned it.
One of the whisperers rolled his eyes.
So I let him.
Then the rain came.
Hard.
Water found the weak seam in the east wall.
Ran straight toward the supply stack.
You know what keeps food dry?
Working drains.
You know who clears drains?
Not the loudest man in the room.
We redirected it.
Proper slope.
Minimal loss.
Afterward—
same fella came up to me.
Didn’t apologize.
Just said, “Didn’t think about that.”
I told him most people don’t.
That’s why floors matter.
That’s why walls matter.
That’s why someone’s gotta notice the little things.
He’s been callin’ me “Mr. Gus” since.
Funny how quick a joke becomes a title.
I don’t need praise.
But I won’t be dismissed either.
World’s still endin’.
But it’s standin’ on clean tile.
Gus out.
And check your drains before the storm does.
________________


FINAL TRANSMISSION — “Level”
Gus:
Alright.
We’re packin’ up the radio.
Johnson says we’ll need it mobile.
Spread the signal.
Makes sense.
School’s secure enough now.
Doesn’t need broadcastin’ as much as it needs maintainin’.
And I’ve got that covered.
Kids are louder these days.
In a good way.
Chairs get moved.
Boots get scuffed.
Life’s messy.
I’ve made peace with that.
…
There’s somethin’ I should probably say.
Been callin’ my mop Linda.
Some of you might’ve guessed.
That was my wife’s name.
She hated when I brought work home.
Said I talked more about floor wax than feelings.
She wasn’t wrong.
But she understood pride.
Understood doin’ a job right.
Understood that order’s a kind of love.
So I named the mop after her.
Figured if I was gonna keep somethin’ upright in this world,
it might as well carry her name.
…
And if my boys are out there—
You don’t gotta follow in my footsteps.
You don’t gotta polish anything.
Just stand level.
That’s enough.
I love you.
…
School’s lookin’ good.
Community’s steady.
Johnson’s got structure.
Erin’s got signal.
And I’ve got tile.
That’s a solid foundation.
This is Gus.
Signing off.
Keep your corners clean.
